city: Marrowgate is a city built within and around the titanic fossil of a sky-wyrm whose ribs arch like alabaster bridges over a chasm carved by the River of No Echo. Seven districts, called the Seven Ribs, ring a central hollow where the sternum once lay, now paved as Sternum Plaza and lined with scrimshawed obelisks that tally treaties, debts, and dead. The Skull Keep crowns the northern brink, its cavernous eye-sockets lantern-lit as the council hall glows within the cranial vault. The First Rib is dockside and damp, ruled by sluice-gates and the cant of boatmen; the Second Rib smokes with kilns and bone-lime; the Third Rib chants with reliquaries and prayer; the Fourth Rib instructs with bone-lore and osteomancy; the Fifth Rib hawks, haggles, and files serrated wares in the Bone-Market; the Sixth Rib parades bone-inlaid townhouses and the scribe-banks; the Seventh Rib sprawls in lantern-dim alleys and rope-bridges along the tailward ward. Established three centuries ago when scavengers-turned-settlers traced the wyrm’s vertebral canal to springwater and safety during the Ash Rains, Marrowgate rose from survival into a center of bonecraft, canal mastery, and contract-magic. Its currency is the chit, a scrimshawed sliver whose carvings match paired registries held by the Loom of Names. Governance nominally belongs to the Custodian of the Remains—currently Lady Sereth Vex—but practical power resides with the Council of Cartilages, guild delegates who argue beneath ribs that creak when oaths are broken. Legends say the wyrm died dueling the Lantern King, a fallen star sovereign whose surrender etched the chasm’s course; others claim the wyrm chose to sleep here to pin shut a wound in the world. On windless nights, the bones hum with river-tremor, and those who listen swear they catch words. Taboos forbid the breaking of bearing-bones, the selling of names without consent, and the summoning of voices from the Mire of Quiet Dust. Prosperity depends on the river gates, bone ash for kilns, trade with the Nadiri caravans, and a delicate truce with the Grave-Binders, whose sigil-cord oaths keep the city’s dead at rest. Conflicts fester between artisans who profit by burning relics and priests who guard them, between scribes who own debts and smugglers who erase them, between zealots who would wake the wyrm and wardens who would drown them in lockwater.

surroundings.name: Ossuary Dunes
surroundings.description: A bleached expanse of pulverized bone and wind-carved femurs jutting like reef spines. Hidden vaults lie beneath whistling vents where bone meal feeds blind fungi.
surroundings.legend: Caravaneers swear a whale of sand and ribs swims beneath the dunes, its song luring lost travelers to shallow graves; those who offer a carved tooth are said to be guided to shade.
surroundings.secrets: Fragments of pre-wyrm ossature protrude after storms—denser and impervious to decay—coveted by the Calcifiers’ Guild for royal commissions.

surroundings.name: Skyfall Shardfield
surroundings.type: Meteoric glass and star-metal strewn plain
surroundings.distance: Two days west beyond the chalk step
surroundings.description: Glass-limned craters glitter with knife-edged panes; meteoric nodules vein the soil with cold fire. At dusk the shards ring with faint harmonics.
surroundings.legend: Here the Lantern King fell, and his crown cracked into seven shards; those who lift a shard and live will carry a wick that never dies.
surroundings.secrets: Buried beneath a fused crater lies a sealed chamber whose walls rewrite maps at dusk; only the Cartographer’s Needle resonates a key tone that opens it.

surroundings.name: Mire of Quiet Dust
surroundings.distance: A day and a night east through reed-choked cuts
surroundings.description: Dead reeds and sootwater pools exhale cold. The mud tastes of lime and tar, and old warding cords hang from snag-boughs, half-sunk.
surroundings.legend: The Dustmother wanders in a cloak of breath, offering sleep without dreams; accept twice and you never wake.
surroundings.secrets: Ancient plague altars bear intact sigils for pacifying the recently dead; the Grave-Binders refresh these bindings every solstice at great political risk.
hazards: Silent currents that drown lantern light

surroundings.name: Silica Reef
surroundings.distance: Three days northwest along the upland shelf
surroundings.description: A forest of translucent spires tuning themselves in wind, home to vitreous ants and the rare glass-bloom whose petals cut and heal in equal measure.
surroundings.legend: The Glass Choir sings when a truthful lie is told beneath its boughs; some say they echo the wyrm’s heart.
surroundings.secrets: A buried furnace-city predates Marrowgate; its smoke channels align with the Seven Ribs and teach kiln magic to those who listen.
hazards: Mirage paths that reflect endless self

surroundings.name: The River of No Echo
surroundings.distance: Directly beneath Marrowgate’s sternum and docks
surroundings.description: Water that swallows sound, coursing through black limestone; the sluiceworks bleed it into canals under oath-bound control.
surroundings.legend: Those who drown here are not heard by death and drift back in dreams to bargain; offerings of coin-chits return curiously unscribed.
surroundings.secrets: A sumped vault beneath the Skull Keep collects relic-silt that prophets brew into an ink that writes itself.
hazards: Blind eels that nest in warm blood

surroundings.name: The Cartographer’s Needle
surroundings.distance: Two and a half days northeast beyond the basalt flats
surroundings.description: A slate-black spire with etched lattices that hum in step with the city’s ribs at dawn and dusk.
surroundings.legend: Maps laid at its base redraw their borders as the light turns, revealing routes that exist only at certain tides of moon and council will.
surroundings.secrets: When sounded with a bone flute cut to Fourth Rib pitch, a door opens beneath the Needle’s shadow to an archive of roads-that-could-be.
hazards: Vagrants in service to a nameless map

surroundings.name: The Hollow March
surroundings.distance: Four days north along the spine trail
surroundings.description: Menhir fields arranged like ribcages under the sky, drumming at night with storm beatings.
surroundings.legend: When the Seventh Rib breaks, stone soldiers will stand and walk to finish the wyrm’s last war.
surroundings.secrets: A bone-bell buried under the central stone answers only to the Custodian’s blood; it summons the oldest council, whether they wish it or not.
hazards: Waking menhirs that lean to listen

buildings.name: Skull Keep
buildings.location: Northern brink within the wyrm’s skull
buildings.description: Fortified galleries and lantern-lit eye halls house the Council of Cartilages and the Custodian’s chambers. The Foramen Ovale chamber resonates oaths into the bone.
buildings.history: Raised from scaffold to stone over the first century, incorporating the natural cavities of the cranium; besieged once during the Kiln Riots.
dependencies: Riverwardens for supply via inner hoist
Grey Lanterns for courier and counter-espionage
Loom of Names for transcript and seal
buildings.legends: If the skull’s sutures sweat, betrayal is being planned within; the last time it happened, a councillor vanished into the vertebral well.
conflicts: Calcifiers’ Guild seeks a permanent voting seat equal to the Custodian’s voice
Order of the Third Rib contests the Keep’s claim over relic licensing
buildings.currentStatus: Garrisoned, with increased watch due to Grey Lantern warnings
notableFigures: Lady Sereth Vex, Custodian of the Remains
Clerk-Major Orin Kell of the Loom of Names

buildings.name: Sternum Plaza
buildings.location: City center where the sternum once lay
buildings.description: A sunken oval paved in bone-tile mosaics showing the city’s founding; market arcades and public speakers’ rings ringed by oath-posts.
buildings.history: Dedicated after the Accords of Quiet Dust as neutral ground. Here debts are sung and matched to name-ledgers under lantern light.
dependencies: Order of the Third Rib wardens
Guild hawkers of the Fifth Rib
buildings.legends: A whisper uttered at the central inlay appears as frost on the bones at next dawn, legible only to those named in the whisper.
conflicts: Smuggler stalls versus scribe taxation
Grave-Binders imposing funerary embargoes during plague scares
buildings.currentStatus: Busy from dawn through second lantern, tense near quarter-day

buildings.name: The Pale Collegium
buildings.type: Academy of osteomancy and natural philosophy
buildings.description: Arcaded courtyards, bone-libraries, and theaters of dissection. Its bell chimes in resonant tones that calm unrest—or rattle marrow.
buildings.history: Founded by refugee scholars who mapped the wyrm’s channels to cure the Quiet Dust; now the city’s prime school of binding, anatomy, and canal physics.
dependencies: Calcifiers for specimens and legal remains
Ember Kiln Syndicate for laboratory ceramics
buildings.legends: A hidden theater teaches the language of ribs; speak it and the city answers.
conflicts: Order of the Third Rib disputes vivisection of relic fauna
Grey Lanterns pressure faculty to redact star-metal studies
buildings.currentStatus: Lecture season in full session; restricted archives under seal

buildings.name: Bone-Market Arches
buildings.description: Stacked stalls beneath rib-spanned arches sell carved vertebrae, inlaid tympani drums, and oath-chord trinkets.
buildings.history: Grew from informal shambles into licensed vaults following the Chit Reforms; the Calcifiers’ Guild supervises tools and measures.
buildings.legends: The arch keystones speak prices to those who have never lied in a sale.
conflicts: Counterfeit chit rings undermining prices
Kiln Syndicate baiting markets with under-fired glass

buildings.name: Cathedral of the Third Rib
buildings.description: A basilica set under the third arc, housing the Warden’s Altar and the Long Shelf of Names for the unclaimed dead.
buildings.history: Consecrated on the fiftieth year to seal the last plague pit; received the Bone Bell from the Hollow March as a sign of guardianship.
buildings.legends: If the Bone Bell tolls without a hand, an oath has been murdered.
conflicts: Ember Kiln Syndicate’s demand for bone ash access
Cult of the Hollow Pilgrims attempting relic thefts
buildings.currentStatus: Open to petitioners; reliquary vaults reinforced

buildings.name: First Rib Sluiceworks
buildings.description: Chains rattle through bone-crowned wheels that lift silence-soaked water into the upper pools; lock-keepers read pressure like scripture.
buildings.history: Built in stages with star-metal bearings from Skyfall to quiet gate-song; never conquered, even during the Ugden Flood.
dependencies: Loom of Names for flow ledgers
buildings.legends: If the gates hum the old hymn, the river brings a lost fleet home.
conflicts: Smuggling routes tunneled by Seventh Rib crews
Council austerity starving maintenance crews
buildings.currentStatus: Operational; one gate offline pending bearing replacement

buildings.name: Ember Kilnworks
buildings.description: Terraced furnaces fed with bone ash and silica; a red glare paints the rib at night, and slag falls into cooled gutters.
buildings.history: Merged from three rival kilns after the Ember Compact; rebuilt twice following explosions rumored to be sabotage.
buildings.legends: A hidden chamber hardens glass that sings to the touch, revealing lies by a disharmonic note.
conflicts: Order of the Third Rib embargoing relic ash
Dock unions striking over heat tithe
buildings.currentStatus: Running at two-thirds capacity; quality fluctuates

buildings.name: The Wyrmwell
buildings.type: Guarded shaft and descent into vertebral canal
buildings.description: A vertiginous well lined with ribbed stair and winch; the air is cold and smells of old storms. Lantern runes mark measured depths.
buildings.history: First breach into the canal was accidental during a well-dig; exploration halted after three crews vanished beyond a sealed cartilage gate.
dependencies: Order of the Third Rib for warding
buildings.legends: At its nadir the wyrm’s last breath sleeps as a weather that can be bottled and poured out as wind.
conflicts: Prospectors versus wardens over opening the cartilage gate
Hollow Pilgrim sabotage of winches

buildings.name: The Scribehouse of the Loom of Names
buildings.description: A cool hall of inkstone and bone screens where names are bought, pledged, and redeemed; a thousand cords hang cataloging lives.
buildings.history: Raised after the Chit Reforms, binding currency to name-threads; during the Kiln Riots it negotiated the peace by freezing all ledgers.
buildings.legends: A blank cord awaits the city’s own name; when braided, Marrowgate will choose its fate.
conflicts: Grey Lanterns attempting to anonymize couriers
Nadiri complaints over external name taxation

buildings.name: Phosphor House
buildings.location: Edge of the Fourth and Seventh Rib boundary
buildings.description: A retired light-tower refit with shutter-lamps and whisper-tubes threading the underways; its windows glow low-green at moonrise.
buildings.history: Built as a river signal beacon, annexed in secret by the Grey Lanterns during the Star-Wasp Summer to coordinate evacuation.
buildings.legends: Its lamp shutters can spell truths that cannot be heard by ears; only reflections can read them.
conflicts: Loom of Names warrants for shutter logs
Calcifiers complaining of lamp glass requisitions
buildings.currentStatus: Denied as official property; plainly occupied

politics.name: Calcifiers' Guild
politics.type: Artisan guild of bonecraft and articulation
politics.motive: Control the city’s bone economy, elevate bonecraft to noble art, secure exclusive access to rare ossature.
politics.history: Formed from carvers and joint-setters who saved the city during the Quiet Dust by reconstructing ventilations; gained power via the Chit Reforms tying artisan marks to currency validation.
politics.influence: High in Fifth and Sixth Ribs; two votes on the Council of Cartilages pending recognition of a third.
customs: Initiates swear on a joint they have repaired

politics.name: Riverwardens of the No Echo
politics.motive: Maintain flow sovereignty, collect lock tithes, suppress smuggling, and keep the river’s silence contained.
politics.history: Sworn from fisher clans and ropewright families; earned citywide trust after holding gates through the Ugden Flood and quelling the Lockbreaker Mutiny without bloodshed.
politics.influence: Controls essential infrastructure; conservative block on the Council.
customs: Silent toast before raising a gate

politics.name: Order of the Third Rib
politics.type: Religious wardens of relics and funerary law
politics.motive: Guard the Remains, honor the dead, prevent necromantic abuses, and bind the city to its vows.
politics.history: Sanctified precincts during the Quiet Dust plague; codified the Accords of Quiet Dust to limit necromancy and protect remains.
politics.influence: Moral authority in Third and First Ribs; swing vote on charter amendments.
customs: Lantern vigils on the wyrm’s Deathday

politics.name: Ember Kiln Syndicate
politics.type: Industrial consortium of glass, tile, and ash-ceramic makers
politics.motive: Secure raw materials, dominate kiln technology, and outcompete foreign imports.
politics.history: Merged rivals after the Ember Compact; accused of arson in the Glass Tax Revolt, charges never proven.
politics.influence: Economic clout and guild muscle; leverages employment in Second Rib to sway street politics.

politics.name: Loom of Names
politics.motive: Bind credit to names, ensure contracts endure, and keep the city’s history legible and owned.
assets: Scribehouse of the Loom of Names
politics.history: Rose during the Chit Reforms, replacing trust with measured ledger-cords; famously froze all accounts to end the Kiln Riots.
politics.influence: Touches every transaction; feared, petitioned, and resented.
seats: Scribehouse of the Loom of Names
customs: Cord blessing at birth and partnership

politics.name: Grey Lanterns
politics.motive: Control information flows, protect messengers, and keep certain truths alive and certain lies dead.
politics.history: Began as lantern-bearers for night funerals; became indispensable during the Star-Wasp Summer by coordinating quarantines and evacuations.
politics.influence: Soft power in every ward; kingmakers in close votes via rumor cascades.
taboos: Speaking your own name on duty
Carrying two truths in one tongue

politics.name: Grave-Binders
politics.motive: Ensure the Accords of Quiet Dust are observed, bind the restless, and harness the dead’s counsel without slavery.
politics.history: Formed in the plague years when the dead walked not in malice but in confusion; codified legal bindings and rights of the departed.
politics.influence: Respected, feared; can halt industries by invoking funerary quarantine.
taboos: Compelling speech from the unconsenting dead
customs: Ash-marking on the brow during vows

politics.name: Nadiri Caravan Court
politics.type: Confederation of riverstep nomads and traders
politics.motive: Preserve caravan rights, set fair tolls, and protect Nadiri custom within city walls.
leaders: Waymother Safra of the Nine Bridges
politics.history: Preceded Marrowgate by generations, guiding early settlers along bone-sheltered routes; codified the Salt-Tithe that the Riverwardens now contest.
politics.influence: External leverage; vital supply lines grant bargaining power against gate closures.
taboos: Eating alone on a road day
